executive_summary: Through some of the past five years, falling unemployment and rising per capita disposable income benefited commercial embroidery servicers. While the decade-long trend of large multifunctional apparel companies integrating embellishment processes into their operations poses a threat to operators, stable underlying demand from commercial buyers in need of providing embroidered uniforms to an increasing number of employees initially kept operators' revenue steady. However, this core market, coupled with downstream buyers which include the administrative and hospitality sectors, endured a sharp fall in demand in 2020 due to COVID-19, significantly hampering core revenue channels and demand streams for operators' services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue falling at CAGR of 2.8% over past 5 years
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Revenue for commercial embroidery services has been falling at a CAGR of 2.8% over the past five years, and is expected to reach $1.1 billion through the end of 2023. This includes an expected 0.1% slip in 2023, when the profit margin is poised to reach 3.7%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile economic conditions harmed core demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Commercial embroidery servicers are highly dependent on stability across the economy to ensure consistent revenue growth, a trend that was severely disrupted during the COVID-19 pandemic. A severe spike in the national unemployment rate in 2020 significantly harmed demand among individual consumers, who require commercial embroidery services for personalized apparel.

Since embroidery services are embraced across a wide variety of sectors within the domestic economy, consumers will look to procure services that are the most cost-efficient in the market. The heavy emphasis on manufacturing creates a strong connection with domestic and international manufacturing trends, as higher rates of import penetration negatively harm domestic operators' ability to provide services beneficial to revenue growth.

Although broader economic conditions have harmed operators, the implementation of new technology and customization options provided a unique ability to streamline production and improve customer service. If apparel companies offer customization services, they set themselves up for improved customer relations and open their product line across a larger customer base, which benefits commercial embroidery servicers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic recovery to bolster long-term prospects
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As economic conditions fully recover following the COVID-19 pandemic, operators will look to leverage improved demand from downstream customers and larger apparel manufacturers to bolster embroidery service output.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Vertically integrated companies to temper growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The prevalent popularity of embroidery services and the push to lower production costs will incentivize external competitors to push for in-house development of embroidery services and accelerate automation at production facilities.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Import penetration to strain revenue growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Commercial embroidery servicers continue to face significant import penetration from abroad, as apparel manufacturers look to take advantage of low labor costs in developing countries, such as Bangladesh and Vietnam. The offshoring of embroidery services will continue to be a noteworthy revenue constraint.

industry_definition: Operators primarily provide embroidery services to clients. The embroidery process involves the use of a sewing machine that creates predetermined patterns on clothing and other textiles. These patterns can be designed using specialist software. Services are often sold to companies, teams and clubs for shirts, uniforms and other paraphernalia.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Operators are subject to environmental laws and regulations regarding the discharge of waste and chemicals into the environment. The Environmental Protection Agency requires operators to comply with the Clean Air Act of 1970 and the Clean Water Act of 1977. These federal acts state the level of chemical discharge that is permitted into the air and into waterways. Various state and local environmental regulations are also imposed on operators.

Commercial embroidery servicers must comply with copyright laws on designs for digitized commercial embroidery software. An example of a law implemented for this regulation is the Digital Millenium Copyright Act (DMCA), which provides the framework to protect against copyright infringement. This continues to gain traction, as the implementation of new technology and acceleration of software usage to design embroidery patterns creates the potential for copyright violations.

To prevent the spread of COVID-19, in March 2020, most state governments ordered nonessential businesses to temporarily close. Additional safety measures include the implementation of mask mandates and social distancing guidelines to protect workers at the facilities. As the COVID-19 vaccine continued to be rolled out, many states lifted these restrictions, with operators reopening on a case-by-case basis.

Limited margins and high costs like wages limit opportunities for expansion.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: VOLATILITY IN GLOBAL SUPPLY CHAIN DERAILS PROFITABILITY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Recent growth in inflationary pressures dampened profit, as higher costs of input goods, such as synthetic fiber, curtailed operators' profit margin, even as broader economic conditions improved following COVID-19.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: CONSISTENT DEMAND FOR QUALIFIED LABOR FORCE STRENGTHENS WAGE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Operators require a variety of staff that is needed to streamline embroidery services and be proficient with the latest computer and digital software systems. Although automation continues to be implemented, there is still widespread usage of raw labor, with higher emphasis on qualifications spurring higher wage costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: SPIKE IN INFLATIONARY PRESSURES EXACERBATES PURCHASE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Commercial embroidery servicers work with a variety of fabrics and threads, which require raw materials such as cotton, synthetic fibers, threads and dyes.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Consistent Need for Quality Service Enhances Administrative Expenses
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Some of the other costs accrued by operators include administrative and legal fees, insurance and freight costs, which are necessary to maintain steady functioning of an operator's facilities. As operators continue to expand across local markets, it creates a higher administrative cost to ensure processing of orders and strong customer service.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Commercial embroidery services endured a low level of capital intensity. IBISWorld estimates in 2023, for every $1.00 spent on wages, operators will spend $0.05 on capital investment. Capital investment is mainly in replacements and improvements of machinery and equipment. However, operators are increasing their usage of leasing arrangements to finance greater capital expenditures.

Over the past five years, capital intensity has remained stagnant, although operators are increasingly attempting to stay competitive by investing in new technologies. As the wage costs associated with employing high-skill labor increases in line with capital investment, capital intensity has remained steady.

Meanwhile, capital depreciation expenses have declined over the past five years despite purchasing and implementing automated manufacturing processes has yielded an increased investment in embroidery machinery; automation has become a paramount concern for companies vying to gain market share in this highly competitive industry.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The improvement of economic conditions following the COVID-19 pandemic helped stabilize core revenue channels for operators. Nonetheless, uncertainty over the national unemployment rate and broader inflationary pressures will enhance volatility and force operators to manage.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Continued Proliferation of Import Substitutes Heightens Growth Uncertainty
volatility_points.volatility_description: As apparel manufacturers continue to drive offshoring and outsourcing efforts in an attempt to lower production costs, it creates a wave of uncertainty for domestic operators. Since imported goods are significantly less expensive, it exacerbates price-based competition for operators, adding to uncertainty across core revenue channels.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Commercial embroidery services are not subject to a significant level of disruption from technological changes. While digitization software has enabled operators to synchronize digital embroidery machines with online platforms, technological advancement has not provided avenues to disrupt the current business model of the industry. Instead, technological change has continued to erode the role of labor in the industry as processes continue to be automated.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Commercial embroidery services endured a moderate degree of technological change over the past decade
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Greater development of digitization software has enabled operators to synchronize digital embroidery machines with online platforms. These systems enable commercial embroiderers to create designs through their computer and then apply the design. Additional developments have centered on improving overall speed and color-change automation for commercial embroidery machines.

The laser bridge machine is one of the latest pieces of equipment introduced. The machine is designed to complete applique and etching on ready-to-wear apparel, an embroidering segment that has been growing over the past five years. The laser bridge machine enables commercial embroiderers to automate the applique process and provides better accuracy.

Recent developments have also focused on large-format embroidery machines and remote control. Large format machines are designed specifically for oversized designs for jackets, blankets, tablecloths and other products. Further, tablet-based embroidery machines, such as the Tajima Sidekick by Pulse, enables users to create text, set up designs, manage the machine and check the status of a design from a tablet.

FAQs.question: How have economic changes influenced consumer demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: As economic conditions continue to improve and unemployment falls, demand from downstream buyers, including the administrative and hospitality sectors, has risen. Commercial buyers looking to provide embroidered uniforms to an increasing number of employees has driven industry revenue growth.

FAQs.question: Does your company face significant competition from substitute goods or services?
FAQs.answer: Operators significantly compete with large multifunctional apparel companies integrating embellishment processes into their operations, thereby offering substitute services.

FAQs.question: To what degree are your operations capital intensive?
FAQs.answer: Operators endure a low level of capital intensity. In 2023, for every dollar spent on wages, the average operator is estimated to spend $0.05 in capital.

FAQs.question: What is your company's most significant operational expense?
FAQs.answer: The largest single component in the average cost structure is purchases. These include raw materials, such as cotton and synthetic fibers, threads and dyes. Purchase costs are anticipated to account for 41.4% of revenue in 2023.

FAQs.question: Has investment in new technologies increased your company's competitiveness?
FAQs.answer: Greater development of digitization software has enabled companies to create designs through their computer and then apply those designs to apparel. This has boosted production efficiency while simultaneously improving product quality.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to minimize/reduce wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: During the five-year period, labor costs are expected to rise as a portion of revenue. Companies have increasingly turned to automation in order to minimize rising labor costs. As a result, depreciation costs are also expected to inch upward as a share of revenue over the period.

FAQs.question: Do you work with industry associations or other groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: There are many associations that provide various forms of assistance to industry companies, including the National Association for the Sewn Products Industry, the Textile Society of America and the Embroiderers' Guild of America.

FAQs.question: What are the toughest regulatory requirements that your company experiences?
FAQs.answer: Companies are subject to environmental laws and regulations regarding the discharge of waste and chemicals into the environment. Companies must also comply with copyright laws on designs for digitized commercial embroidery software.

FAQs.question: How has your company's profitability trended over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Profit is anticipated to have risen over the past five years, as falling unemployment levels have stimulated rising downstream demand for industry products, allowing operators to increase selling prices.

FAQs.question: Is your company looking to significantly expand its operations sometime in the near future?
FAQs.answer: Commercial embroidery servicers are primarily comprised of small, retail-oriented storefronts that cater to both commercial businesses and the general public. It is unlikely that these companies will make investments to significantly expand their small-scale operations in the near future.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain skilled employees? Are there channels for promotion and career development within your company?
FAQs.answer: Changes in downstream demand can alter workflows and production requirements of employees. Operators that have a workforce that is able to adapt to these changes can provide the market with products in a shorter period of time.

FAQs.question: What new technologies and techniques does your company use? How quickly can new technology be adopted?
FAQs.answer: To gain an advantage over operators from countries with less expensive labor, US companies can use technologically advanced equipment and machinery to lower costs and improve quality.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts with key distributors and end-users? Are you located close to your target markets and suppliers?
FAQs.answer: To minimize revenue volatility, companies should form relationships with local businesses, promotional product distributors, apparel manufacturers and other key markets.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your sales are to apparel manufacturing? How do you compensate for declines in demand from this segment?
FAQs.answer: Since apparel manufacturers comprise a major market for the Commercial Embroidery Services industry, revenue is closely tied to activity in this manufacturing sector.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? Are certain products more affected by changes in disposable income than others?
FAQs.answer: As consumers' disposable incomes grow, demand for embroidered apparel increases, heightening the need for operators' services.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor unemployment rates to plan your business accordingly? How has the national unemployment rate affected your company thus far?
FAQs.answer: Most of the commercial embroidery services are used for employee uniforms. When unemployment falls, demand for embroidery services from this market increases as there are more workers who need embroidered uniforms.
